#inmemory#

CS 513: Theory and Practice of Data Cleaning Syllabus

Course Description

Welcome to CS 513: Theory & Practice of Data Cleaning!

In this course, you will learn about common data quality problems and about methods and tools to improve data quality, i.e., how to "clean" data for subsequent data analysis. Data cleaning is an essential but often under-appreciated part of data science. Some surveys report that data scientists spend the majority of their cleaning, wrangling, or “munging” data before data is actually ready to be analyzed. This course is an introduction to the theory and practice of data cleaning. We will first provide a brief overview on different dimensions of data quality. We will then turn our attention to syntactic (i.e., pattern-based) data quality issues. In the first hands-on module, we will work with regular expressions to match and extract data. We will then use OpenRefine, a powerful open source tool for cleaning individual data columns (e.g., through common transformations and operations that are used to obtain a canonical form of data). Moving on from syntactic to schema and semantic issues, we will work with both Datalog (a logic-based rule language) and SQL(ite) to express and check high-level integrity constraints. Finally, we will learn about workflow automation, provenance modeling and capture, and provenance querying, which allows users to reveal dependencies in data cleaning workflows and make data cleaning more transparent, reusable, and reproducible.

New (Summer 2024): While content (recorded lectures, assignments, etc) are ready from Week 1 (5/13/2024), we will also introduce additional materials throughout the summer, in the form of Fireside Chats , new quizzes, and problem sets. For example, we plan to provide an introduction to a powerful rule-based system ( Logica ) that can be used to validate integrity constraints (ICs) but also to query provenance and do data science analytics declaratively. These additional materials are strictly optional but provide a way (for us) to test new materials, and (for you) to obtain extra credit. More on that during the first weeks (see campuswire).

Course Goals and Objectives

Upon successful completion of this course, you will be able to:

  • Recognize common data quality problems and associate them with data quality dimensions.

  • Develop simple regular expressions for matching, extracting, and transforming data.

  • Use OpenRefine to explore and profile data, to identify data quality issues, and to clean and normalize data using its powerful built-in functions (e.g., for clustering and "fusing" similar data strings into canonical ones).

  • Use declarative constraints, expressed as Datalog (Logica) rules and SQL queries, to check the validity of datasets with respect to a given set of integrity constraints spanning one or more data tables.

  • Use a simple annotation language to create and visualize workflow models that reveal dataflow dependencies hidden in data analysis scripts in Python, R, etc.

  • Use rule-based queries on provenance graphs to explore the lineage and processing history of data from workflows and scripts.

Textbook and Readings

There is no textbook that you are required to purchase for this course. Instead, the following textbooks will be used throughout the course for additional readings. They are available online through the University of Illinois Library:

  • [IC19] Ilyas, I. F., & Chu, X. (2019). Data cleaning . Morgan & Claypool.

  • [GS13] Ganti, V., & Sarma, A. D. (2013). Data cleaning: A practical perspective . Synthesis Lectures on Data Management, 5(3), 1-85.

  • [Sad13a] Sadiq, S. (Ed). (2013). Handbook of data quality: Research and practice . Springer Science & Business Media.

The following are some of the readings that accompany the weekly lecture materials:

  • [ACD+16] Abedjan, Z., Chu, X., Deng, D., Fernandez, R. C., Ilyas, I. F., Ouzzani, M., Papotti, P., Stonebraker, M., & Tang, N. (2016). Detecting data errors: Where are we and what needs to be done ? Proc. VLDB Endow., 9 (12), 993–1004.

  • [BB13] Bertossi, L., & Bravo, L. (2013). Generic and declarative approaches to data quality management . In Handbook of data quality (pp. 181-211). Springer.

  • [BCF+09] Batini et al. (2009). Methodologies for Data Quality Assessment and Improvement . ACM Computing Surveys, 2009.

  • [GH13] Ge, M. & Helfert, M. (2013). Cost and Value Management for Data Quality . In Handbook of Data Quality.

  • [RD00] Rahm, E., & Do, H. H. (2000). Data cleaning: Problems and current approaches . IEEE Data Eng. Bull., 23 (4), 3-13.

  • [Red13] Redman, T. (2013). Data Quality Management Past, Present, and Future: Towards a Management System for Data . In Handbook of Data Quality , 15–40.

  • [Sad13b] Sadiq, S. (2013). Prologue: Research and practice in data quality management . In Handbook of data quality (pp. 1-11). Springer.

Elements of This Course

The course is comprised of the following elements:

  • Lecture Videos. Each week, the concepts you need to know will be presented through a collection of short video lectures. You may stream these videos for playback within the browser by clicking on their titles or download the videos.

  • Weekly Quizzes : There is a quiz on the material at the end of each week. These quizzes are intended as a studying and learning activity and can be repeated with your highest score retained for the final grade.

  • Homework Assignments. There are six homework assignments in this course. Homework assignments are machine auto-graded programming assignments. You will have unlimited attempts on all homework. All homework should be submitted before the deadline. The homework is designed to allow you to gain a deeper understanding of the course content using practical exercises.

  • Data Cleaning Group Project . The data cleaning project is a conclusive project of the entire class. It requires you to integrate the knowledge and skills you gained from the entire course.

  • Online Forum and Office Hours . This course will use a Campuswire-based discussion forum. The instructor and teaching assistants will be participating in the online forum and also offer online office hours. See the Communications page for details.

Late Submission Policy

Quiz

The quizzes for Weeks 1-5 must be completed by the end of Week 6 , and the quizzes for Weeks 6-10 must be completed by the end of Week 11 . Late quizzes will receive a 20% deduction. No quizzes will be accepted after August 4th.

Homework

In this course, each homework will be released by the week started or earlier. It is highly recommended that students finish the homework by the recommended submission date, but to be flexible, we have extended the deadline one week later by default to ensure that students will have two weeks to complete each assignment. Thus, you should strictly follow the deadline of each assignment according to the table above.

  • Late assignment submissions made after the deadline will receive a 20% deduction from the total grade on the assignment.

  • Submissions made one or more weeks after the deadline will not receive any grade (0 Points) for the assignment.

With special circumstances that may delay you from completing the homework on time, you should email mcs-support@illinois.edu ahead of time to let the course team know.

Group Project

The project will be announced in Week 4. The group project is staff graded and will require time from the TA's to complete their grading. These deadlines are strict and projects handed in after their deadline will be penalized at the rate of 10% per day with a limit of 7 days.

Course Withdrawn and Refund

For course withdrawn-related questions, please refer to the Academic Calendars at http://registrar.illinois.edu/academic-calendars and select Summer 2024 on that page.

For course refund information, please refer to the Office of the Registrar refunds website: http://registrar.illinois.edu/refunds and select Summer 2024 term. You can also refer to this website for the pro-rate refund schedule if you plan to withdraw from the course after the first day of classes for any given semester.

Academic Calendar

  • The Graduate College at the University of Illinois maintains a Graduate College Calendar . The calendar includes important dates such as final exam dates, course registration and cancellation, and holidays.

  • There is also a campus-wide calendar available.

  • The CS Department also sends reminders about upcoming deadlines. You will also receive the Graduate College newsletter in your Exchange email account.

Course Communication

When you are in need of help, please follow the two simple steps below to reach out to us.

  1. We will use Campuswire for all course related questions such as clarification on lecture videos and any course assignments. Before you post, please check if someone has already asked your question. The instructor and TA will attempt to answer questions within 24 hours . Questions posted questions at the last minute risk not being answered in time. Please try and check Campuswire on a regular basis.

  2. Email mcs-support@illinois.edu for non-content related questions in particular administrative questions you have for course staff or technical issues with the platform. We are committed to answering your questions within 24 - 48 hours during the working week.

To join Campuswire for Summer 2024 use the following invitation link and then enter the code: 4907 .

Instructor Office Hours

There will be several Office Hours per week (instructor's and TA's office hours will be spread across different days and times). In addition the instructor will offer regular " fireside chats ", i.e., optional and informal synchronous lectures and Q&As. Recordings of these events will be shared within a day or two of the event. Watch Campuswire for announcements!

Zoom

Office hours and fireside chats will be hosted via Zoom.

Course Help Resources

For Coursera Platform Technical Support

If you have a technical issue, the Coursera Help Center is a great place to start. The Help Center has detailed information on:

  • Account Setup

  • Video troubleshooting and downloads

  • Assignments

  • Peer reviews

  • Degree student features

  • Coursera policies

For Coursera Platform Urgent Technical Support

If you need to speak to someone for urgent technical support, you are very welcome to use our chat support. This support is offered 24 hours a day, 7 days per week. As a degree student, you can access chat support on any page of the Course Help Center .

Remember that Coursera chat support does not always know that you are a degree student. Please let them know that you are a degree student for the MCS-DS program as soon as you start a chat. That way we can ensure that your problem is solved as quickly as possible.

For Zoom Training and Support

  • Zoom Help Center : The Zoom Help Center offers the most comprehensive resources on Zoom. You can type in issues and search for a solution.

  • Zoom Video Tutorials : Video tutorials that can be taken at your own pace.

  • Zoom Technical Webinars : Hosted once every month.

  • Zoom Weekly Training Webinars : Free to register and join. This is a 90-minute user onboarding session with live Q&A. If you can attend, you can also view the latest recording.

  • Zoom 24/7 phone support: Phone dial-in +1.888.799.9666 ext 2 or +1.650.397.6096 ext 2

  • Zoom 24/7 Live Chat : The live chat feature is available at the lower bottom on any Zoom page. You will see a pop-up button that says Help . Click on the Help button and type in the question you have. After typing in your question, you will see the Live chat option to chat with a Zoom Agent.

  • Zoom ticket : Submit a ticket to Zoom for non-urgent account or technical issues.

For Disability Accommodations

To obtain disability-related academic adjustments and/or auxiliary aids, students should contact both the instructor and the Disability Resources and Educational Services (DRES) as soon as possible. You can contact DRES at 1207 S. Oak Street, Champaign, (217) 333-1970 , or via email at disability@illinois.edu . You can also visit the DRES homepage .

#inmemory#

Week 2: Validation and Transformation

Overview

Data validation and transformation refer to the methods of ensuring that data conform to expected structures or formats. Data validation ensures that data match defined rules; whereas data transformations are used to convert from one structure or format to another. This week we will learn about regular expressions, a popular and widespread formalism used in both validation and transformation. A regular expression (or regex ) can be used to match patterns in text data and to extract data from the text. We will first have a brief look at where regular expressions come from (computer science theory) and then take a closer look at the practice of regular expressions. The first hands-on assignment requires the definition of some simple (or not so simple) regular expressions to match common data strings, such as dates or email addresses.

Weekly Readings

  • [IC19, Chapter 4] Data Transformation

  • [GS13, Section 6.1] Regular Expressions

  • RegExr.com: https://regexr.com/

Time

This module should take approximately 6 hours of dedicated time to complete, with its videos and assignments.

Lessons

The lessons for this module are listed below (with assignments in bold italics):

Activity

Estimated Time Required

Lesson 1 Lecture Videos

1 hour

Readings

1 hour

Week 2 Quiz

1 hour

Regular Expressions Homework

3 hours

Goals and Objectives

Upon successful completion of this module, you will be able to:

  • Understand the role of validation and transformation in the data cleaning pipeline and how they can be implemented using regular expressions.

  • Interpret how regular expressions and regular languages fit in a larger theoretical framework of formal languages studied in computer science.

  • From a practical point of view, apply real-world regular expressions to match certain patterns in order to determine whether a data string corresponds to a standard format or not, say the ISO date format.

Key Phrases/Concepts

Keep your eyes open for the following key terms or phrases as you interact with the lectures and complete the activities.

  • The basic regex constructors: in theory : basic label L; and inductively defined expressions such as R|R, RR, R*.

  • In contrast, in practice we have additional operators (e.g., for convenience: R? or R+) and constructs that are crucial for getting things done in practice (e.g., character sets [..], groups (..), special characters \s, \w, \W, etc.).

  • False negatives: the regex should match, but doesn't.

  • False positives: the regex matches, but shouldn't.

  • Not everything that could (in theory) be done with regular expressions, should be done. A "division of labor" (or separation of concerns) uses regex for syntactic issues and code ("business logic") for semantics issues.

  • Regular expressions are not only useful for matching and validation of data patterns, but also for extracting and transformation of data.

Guiding Questions

Develop your answers to the following guiding questions while watching lectures and working on assignments throughout the module.

  • What are regular expressions and how can they help in the larger data cleaning and analysis life-cycle?

  • How would you describe a syntactic pattern, say for a floating point number - in theory (e.g., using a grammar) vs. in practice (using a regex)?

  • What can and can't you do with regular expressions?

#inmemory#

Week 3: Data Profiling and Exploration

Overview

When confronted with a new dataset, data exploration is often the first step of the data cleaning process. Data exploration and visualization methods are used to identify structures, patterns, and develop a strategy for addressing errors and other quality issues. Data profiling is a more structured process used to identify and quantify key characteristics of datasets and potential data quality concerns. Profiling may include identifying cardinalities, data types, value distributions, correlations, constraints, and duplicates.

A variety of tools are available for profiling and exploration, both programmatic and interactive. In this week we focus on OpenRefine, a powerful open-source tool for data cleaning. We will work with two different public datasets that can be used to highlight syntactic data quality issues (i.e., the USDA's Farmers' Markets dataset, and the New York Public Library's collection of historic restaurant menus). We will revisit these datasets at the end of the semester in the final project.

Weekly Readings:

  • [ACD+16] Abedjan, Z., Chu, X., Deng, D., Fernandez, R. C., Ilyas, I. F., Ouzzani, M., Papotti, P., Stonebraker, M., & Tang, N. (2016). Detecting data errors: Where are we and what needs to be done? Proc. VLDB Endow., 9 (12), 993–1004.

  • [AGN15] Abedjan, Z., Golab, L. & Naumann, F. (2015). Profiling relational data: a survey . The VLDB Journal 24, 557–581 (2015).

  • [PT20] Petrova-Antonova, D. & Tancheva, R. (2020). Data Cleaning: A Case Study with OpenRefine and Trifacta Wrangler . In Quality of Information and Communications Technology .

Time

This module should take approximately 7 hours of dedicated time to complete, with its videos, readings, quiz, and assignments.

Lessons

The lessons for this module are listed below (with assignments in bold italics):

Activity

Estimated Time Required

Lesson 1 Lecture Videos

1 hour

Readings

1 hour

Week 3 Quiz

1 hour

OpenRefine Homework

4 hours

Goals and Objectives

Upon successful completion of this module, you will be able to:

  • Identify key data profiling tasks and understand the trade-offs between interactive and non-interactive methods of profiling.

  • Create a new OpenRefine project and load tabular data into the system.

  • Get an overview of a dataset using OpenRefine functions.

  • Apply common syntactic transformations, such as trimming or collapsing white-spaces.

  • Use facets and clustering for creating normalized, canonical names.

  • Improve the data quality of a dataset with OpenRefine.

  • Document and reapply changes made to the data, using OpenRefine's operation history.

Key Phrases/Concepts

Keep your eyes open for the following key terms or phrases as you interact with the lectures and complete the activities.

  • Common transformations

  • Data type conversions

  • Facets (text, timeline, scatterplot)

  • Clustering

  • Normalization of data columns

  • Operation history and provenance

Guiding Questions

Develop your answers to the following guiding questions while watching lectures and working on assignments throughout the module.

  • How can OpenRefine be used for data cleaning?

  • What are some key functions that OpenRefine offers for cleaning data?

  • What are some (theoretical and practical) limitations of OpenRefine?

  • What kinds of data quality issues can and can't be tackled with OpenRefine?

  • How does OpenRefine compare with other tools commonly used for tabular data (e.g., Excel or SQL databases)?

#inmemory#

Week 4: Relational Model and Queries

Overview

The relational model provides a powerful set of techniques for identifying and addressing logical errors in data, both semantic and structural. Through the relational model and query languages, such as Datalog and SQL, widely-available database technologies can be used to identify and address logical errors in data that spans multiple columns or tables. Regardless of whether the data will ultimately be stored in a relational database, these tools can be used to profile data; identify and apply integrity constraints; and repair errors.

This week we introduce (or, for many of you, revisit) some basic notions of the relational model. We will also take a brief look at various query languages for relational data. In subsequent weeks, we move from these theoretical underpinnings to practical hands-on exercises with relational technologies. You might want to review this week's material together with Week 5 and Week 6 -- in particular the Week 6 assignment (Assignment #3, SQLite) includes a walk-through tutorial that will help you understand relational concepts by working hands-on with a small database and queries.

Weekly readings

  • [Ber11] Bertossi, L. (2011). Introduction . In: Database Repairing and Consistent Query Answering . Synthesis Lectures on Data Management. Springer.

  • [FG12] Fan, W., Geerts, F. (2012). Data Quality: An Overview . In: Foundations of Data Quality Management . Synthesis Lectures on Data Management. Springer.

Time

This module should take approximately 3.5 hours of dedicated time to complete, with its videos, readings, and quiz.

Lessons

The lessons for this module are listed below (with assignments in bold italics):

Activity

Estimated Time Required

Lesson 1 Lecture Videos

30 minutes

Readings

2 hour

Week 4 Quiz

1 hour

Goals and Objectives

Upon successful completion of this module, you will be able to:

  • Understand the role and position of relational technologies in data cleaning.

  • Recognize queries in different languages, in particular Datalog and SQL, and identify the common underlying logical core of relational queries.

Key Phrases/Concepts

Keep your eyes open for the following key terms or phrases as you interact with the lectures and complete the activities.

  • Relational model

  • Relation schemas (table structures)

  • Relation instances (database instances)

  • Relational queries in predicate logic, Datalog, SQL, relational algebra

Guiding Questions

Develop your answers to the following guiding questions while watching lectures and working on assignments throughout the module.

  • What kinds of data quality issues can we tackle with relational database technologies?

  • What are the elements of the relational model?

  • How can relational data be queried?

  • What are some pros and cons of common query languages for relational data?

  • Where do relational databases fit in the overall data cleaning workflow?

#inmemory#

Week 5: Datalog and Integrity Constraints

Overview

Simple validation and transformation techniques can be used to address syntactic errors in data, but are not able to address logical errors. For example, they can be used to validate and normalize ZIP code and state abbreviations, but not determine whether the ZIP code/state combination is valid. Logic errors can be identified through the definition of data quality rules in the form of integrity constraints such as functional and inclusion dependencies. Integrity constraints are expressed as logic rules or queries.

In this module we introduce Datalog, a rule-based language for expressing relational queries and integrity constraints. Integrity constraints can be defined and checked with Datalog thus complementing the pattern-based data cleaning in OpenRefine with logic-based data quality checks. We begin with Datalog, because it makes clear the underlying logical kernel of queries and integrity constraints that is sometimes obscured in languages such as SQL.

Weekly readings

  • [BB13] Bertossi, L., & Bravo, L. (2013). Generic and declarative approaches to data quality management . In Handbook of data quality (pp. 181-211). Springer.

  • [IC19, Ch 5] Data Quality Rule Definition and Discovery ( skip rule discovery sections 5.1.1, 5.2.1, 5.3.1 and other constraints 5.4.2-5.4.6)

  • [G21] Google. (2021). Logica: organizing your data queries, making them universally reusable and fun .

Time

This module should take approximately 7 hours of dedicated time to complete, with its videos, readings, quizzes, and assignment.

Lessons

The activities for this module are listed below (with assignments in bold italics):

Activity

Estimated Time Required

Lesson 1 Lecture Videos

1 hour

Readings

1 hour

Quiz

1 hour

Datalog Homework

4 hours

Goals and Objectives

Upon successful completion of this module, you will be able to:

  • Identify integrity constraints such as key constraints, functional dependencies, denial constraints

  • Formulate and execute queries and check integrity constraints as rules in Datalog.

  • Recognize and deal with common Datalog pitfalls (e.g., rules that are not "safe").

Key Phrases/Concepts

Keep your eyes open for the following key terms or phrases as you interact with the lectures and complete the activities.

  • Datalog rules and queries

  • Expressing and checking integrity constraints (ICs) in Datalog

  • "Denial form" of ICs in Datalog

  • Database repair as constraint solving

Guiding Questions

Develop your answers to the following guiding questions while watching lectures and working on assignments throughout the module.

  • What are queries and integrity constraints and how can they be used for data cleaning?

  • What data quality issues can be tackled by relational queries and integrity constraints (versus issues we could or couldn't tackle in OpenRefine)?

  • What is the difference between checking integrity constraints and repairing constraints?

#inmemory#

Problem 1: Rules and Integrity Constraints (Family Data)

Notes about Datalog (Clingo) in the Jupyter Notebook environment:

  • Refer to Clingo with Jupyter Intro before attempting this notebook.

  • It is important to run the following cells first for the rest of the notebook to work. (It's usually a good idea to run cells in order. In case you have run cells out of order and want to start over, simply restart the kernel from the menu.)

  • All clingo cells start with %%clingo .

  • You can run your clingo cell against the facts and rules from a file. set_db_file $filepath sets the file against which your clingo cells will run.

  • The clingo cells are independent of each other. Rules defined in one cell won't be visible in others!

  • When you submit the assignment, we will run your code against different sets of facts. (So don't "hardcode" your answers ;-)

  • If you want to practice a bit more with clingo, you can go to https://potassco.org/clingo/run/ and experiment with the small (but interesting!) examples there. Alternatively, you can install clingo on your own computer: https://potassco.org/doc/start . If you want to go "all in", there is also an online course ( https://teaching.potassco.org/ ). But don't worry: none of this is required to do this assignment!

  • FYI: %%clingo is just a thin wrapper for running the tool in command line mode.

Family data and rules in Datalog (clingo):

  • Consider the family relation which is shown as a graph below (edges point from a parent to a child)! We will work with Datalog rules to query data from this graph and check for integrity violations.

Good luck!!

#inmemory#

Week 6: Integrity Constraints and SQL

Overview

In this week we move from the theoretical and logical foundations of relational data to its main practical incarnation: SQL, the structured query language. We will learn how SQL can be used to formulate queries, which in turn can be used to check the integrity of data similar to the way in which Datalog queries and rules in denial form were used before.

Weekly readings:

  • [AHV95] Abiteboul, S., Hull, R., & Vianu, V. (1995). Foundations of databases . Reading: Addison-Wesley (Chapter 7, 8.1, 8.2, 9.1 only)

  • Readings continued from Week 5

    • [BB13] Bertossi, L., & Bravo, L. (2013). Generic and declarative approaches to data quality management . In Handbook of data quality (pp. 181-211). Springer.

    • [IC19, Ch 5] Data Quality Rule Definition and Discovery (skip rule discovery sections 5.1.1, 5.2.1, 5.3.1 and other constraints 5.4.2-6)

Time

This module should take approximately 8 hours of dedicated time to complete, with its videos, readings, quiz, and assignment.

Lessons

The lessons for this module are listed below (with assignments in bold italics):

Activity

Estimated Time Required

Lesson 1 Lecture Videos

2 hours

Readings

1 hour

Quiz

1 hour

SQL Homework

4 hours

Goals and Objectives

Upon successful completion of this module, you will be able to:

  • Transfer ideas from Datalog to SQL (i.e., expressing ...

  • ... relational queries and

  • ... relational integrity constraints in SQL).

  • Use SQLite to load and query datasets (that might have been preprocessed and partially cleaned with OpenRefine).

Key Phrases/Concepts

Keep your eyes open for the following key terms or phrases as you interact with the lectures and complete the activities.

  • Different types of SQL database systems (traditional multi-user, client-server systems vs. SQLite)

  • SELECT-FROM-WHERE queries in SQL

  • Queries as a means to profile and check data

  • Recursive queries

Guiding Questions

Develop your answers to the following guiding questions while watching lectures and working on assignments throughout the module.

  • How can relational queries and integrity constraints be used to explore profile data and to check the integrity of data?

  • How can you write queries in SQL that filter, combine, or aggregate data?

  • Why and when should you use SQL compared to OpenRefine or Datalog, for example?

#inmemory#

Week 7: Workflows

Overview

In this week and the two weeks that follow, we will look at data cleaning and analysis in the context of workflows and provenance. Workflows are used to describe and automate data cleaning and analysis "pipelines." Workflows can also combine manual or semi-automatic steps (e.g., in OpenRefine) with fully automatic steps (e.g., using Python, R scripts, or SQL queries). We start by studying scientific workflows (i.e., where scientists and researchers automate their data processing and analysis in dedicated systems or using general purposes scripting languages).

Weekly readings

  • [MV19] Mahdavi, M., Neutatz, F., Visengeriyeva, L. & Abedjan, Z. (2019). Towards Automated Data Cleaning Workﬂows . Machine Learning 15: 16.

  • [GC20] Goble, C. et al. FAIR Computational Workflows . Data Intelligence 2, 108–121 (2020).

  • [LB16] Ludäscher, B. (2016). A Brief Tour through Provenance in Scientific Workflows and Databases . In: Lemieux, V. (eds) Building Trust in Information . Springer.

  • [SBI13] Stonebraker, M., Bruckner, D. & Ilyas, I. F. (2013). Data Curation at Scale: The Data Tamer System . In Proceedings of the 6th Biennial Conference on Innovative Data Systems Research (CIDR ’13).

Time

This module should take approximately 4 hours of dedicated time to complete, with its videos and related readings.

Lessons

The lessons for this module are listed below:

Activity

Estimated Time Required

Lesson 1 Lecture Videos

1 hour

Readings

3 hours

Quiz

1 hour

Goals and Objectives

Upon successful completion of this module, you will be able to:

  • Understand the role of workflows and provenance in the data life-cycle.

  • Explain how workflows (as prospective provenance) are related to (traditional retrospective) provenance.

Key Phrases/Concepts

Keep your eyes open for the following key terms or phrases as you interact with the lectures and complete the activities.

  • Workflow automation

  • Workflows as prospective provenance

  • Computational reproducibility

  • Provenance standards (OPM, W3C PROV)

Guiding Questions

Develop your answers to the following guiding questions while watching lectures and working on assignments throughout the module.

  • What are (scientific) workflows used for? What advantages do they bring to researchers?

  • Why do many researchers prefer to use scripting technologies (such as R and Python) over dedicated workflow technologies?

  • How are workflows and provenance related?

  • What is the importance of workflows and provenance in the context of the larger data life-cycle and data cleaning?

#inmemory#

Week 8: Provenance

Overview

In this week we continue with workflows and provenance, focusing on the latter. We take both a wider and a closer look at provenance, including standards such as OPM (Open Provenance Model) and W3C PROV (the official standard of the World Wide Web consortium). We also relate provenance to current uses (e.g., in the National Climate Assessment or a large cyberinfrastructure project [DataONE]).

Weekly Readings:

  • [HDH17] Herschel, M., Diestelkämper, R., & Houssem B.L.. (2017). “ A Survey on Provenance: What for? What Form? What From? ” The VLDB Journal 26(6): 881–906

  • [DS12] Dey, Saumen C., Sven Köhler, Shawn Bowers, and Bertram Ludäscher. (2012). " Datalog as a Lingua Franca for Provenance Querying and Reasoning ." In TaPP 2012.

  • [PML21] Parulian, N. N., McPhillips, T. M. & Ludäscher, B. (2021) A Model and System for Querying Provenance from Data Cleaning Workflows . In Provenance and Annotation of Data and Processes, Springer.

Time

This module should take approximately 8 hours of dedicated time to complete, with its videos, readings, quiz, and assignment.

Lessons

The lessons for this module are listed below (with assignments in bold italics):

Activity

Estimated Time Required

Lesson 1 Lecture Videos

2 hours

Readings

2 hours

Quiz

1 hour

Datalog/Provenance Assignment

3 hours

Goals and Objectives

Upon successful completion of this module, you will be able to:

  • Understand the similarities and differences between different notions of provenance.

  • Understand the role of provenance in data cleaning and the larger data life-cycle.

  • Identify what kinds of approaches can be used for modeling and querying provenance.

Key Phrases/Concepts

Keep your eyes open for the following key terms or phrases as you interact with the lectures and complete the activities.

  • Workflows and prospective provenance ("workflow land")

  • Runtime observables and retrospective provenance ("trace land")

  • Hybrid forms of provenance

Guiding Questions

Develop your answers to the following guiding questions while watching lectures and working on assignments throughout the module.

  • What are similarities and differences between workflows and provenance models?

  • How can workflows and provenance information be used individually and in combination?

  • What questions and queries can be answered using a workflow model and/or provenance information?

#inmemory#

Week 9: YesWorkflow

Overview

In this week we will bring together workflow models (for script-based workflows, for example, in Python or R) and provenance using an emerging open source tool called YesWorkflow. While we have previously looked at YesWorkflow, in this week we will focus on some specific demonstrations of that tool that showcase how hybrid provenance queries can be used to better reveal and query provenance information from script-based workflows.

Weekly Readings

  • [MB15] McPhillips, T., Bowers, S., Belhajjame, K. & Ludäscher, B. (2015). Retrospective provenance without a runtime provenance recorder . in Proceedings of the 7th USENIX Conference on Theory and Practice of Provenance.

  • [PF19] Pimentel, J. F., Freire, J., Murta, L. & Braganholo, V. A. (2019). Survey on Collecting, Managing, and Analyzing Provenance from Scripts . ACM Comput. Surv. 52, 47:1-47:38.

Time

This module should take approximately 3 hours of dedicated time to complete, with its videos and associated readings.

Lessons

The lessons for this module are listed below:

Activity

Estimated Time Required

Lesson 1 Lecture Videos

1 hour

Readings

1 hour

Quiz

1 hour

Goals and Objectives

Upon successful completion of this module, you will be able to:

  • Understand how different forms of provenance can be combined to answer advanced provenance queries.

  • Explore YesWorkflow provenance artifacts and related YesWorkflow demonstrations.

  • Document your own script-based or manual data cleaning workflows using YesWorkflow annotations.

Key Phrases/Concepts

Keep your eyes open for the following key terms or phrases as you interact with the lectures and complete the activities.

  • Prospective, retrospective, and hybrid forms of provenance

Guiding Questions

Develop your answers to the following guiding questions while watching lectures and working on assignments throughout the module.

  • What are the benefits of workflow systems and how can authors of conventional (and highly popular) script-based approaches experience similar benefits?

  • What kinds of provenance information can be extracted from a script? At (or before!) design time? During and after runtime?

  • How can workflow and provenance queries help with assessing the quality of data and the processes that created the data?
